title: How Your TV Is Conning You About Testosterone
text:
Your Privacy Rights Canadian Customers 
Testosterone does some crazy things for your body and, as we've explained in the past, there is a price to pay for living with low levels of the hormone. However, a recent study reveals that an increase in advertisements warning about the dangers of low testosterone has led to a rise in unnecessary testosterone treatments. Many men are seeking out treatment, despite the fact that their testosterone levels are naturally decreasing as a matter of aging. 
"The original approval for testosterone intended it to be used only in a very narrow group of men with very clearly-defined diseases which stop the production of testosterone," the study's lead author, Bradley Layton, told Reuters. "However, much of the use recently has been in men with reduced testosterone levels or some non-specific symptoms like fatigue, loss of muscle mass, reduced libido or lowered mood which may be related to normal aging or other disease conditions."
